description.narrative: Since 2001, AJOAGO with support of main partners is involved in successfully preparedness and response, improving water, sanitationand hygiene services, food security and other programms in rural communities of Mozambique. AJOAGO will prioritize promotion of hygiene with a focus on hand washing is therefore critical, but can only work if communities are fully involved. Perceptions and beliefs within the community can support or hinder a response, so it is important to understand and address them. Social norms, such as shaking hands, must be modified to prevent transmission of the disease. Disease prevention and treatment must be targeted to each community. Communication and information sharing about OVID-19 will be directed to using local languages, and information will be in various formats to address barriers to information related to literacy, language and disability. Women, older people, children, people with disabilities, resettled people, and people with HIV/AIDS experience high vulnerabilities within a community and become even more vulnerable in emergency situations such as cyclone idai and now associated with covid-19 with the province of Sofala having registered 8 positive cases.
